Suburban Propane's Elk Grove (SPEG) Terminal consists of storage of more than 20 million pounds of liquefied propane, high pressure blimps, railcars and tank trucks, and associated transfer piping and valves. The bulk storage tanks (T1 and T2) are both refrigerated, low-pressure steel, aboveground storage tanks. The SPEG Terminal stores and transfers propane, a flammable material, in excess of the threshold planning quantity of 10,000 pounds, making it subject to the California Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (Cal-OSHA's) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, the California Accident Release Prevention Program (CalARP), and the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) Risk Management Program (RMP). All of these programs require implementation of 14 elements of the PSM Program, an offsite consequence analysis for assessing the impact of a release of propane to the community, and a 5-year accident history. The regulations require the offsite consequence analysis be completed for both worst-case and alternate (credible) worst-case scenario. The SPEG Terminal is covered under the CalARP Level 3, as it is subject to Cal-OSHA's PSM standard, has offsite consequences that extend beyond the plant boundary, and could impact sensitive offsite receptors.

The SPEG Terminal is also regulated by the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) under the Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standards (CFATS), which requires comprehensive security standards for site access and product control.

Consistent with the regulatory requirements, the SPEG Terminal has developed emergency response protocols and coordinated with offsite responders, including the Elk Grove Fire Department; Elk Grove Police Department; Sacramento County Sheriff's Department; and the Sacramento Metropolitan Fire District, Consumnes River Division. Moreover, the SPEG Terminal maintains onsite fire-fighting and emergency response systems and equipment to support and augment offsite emergency

response resources but are not equipped nor trained to respond to fires.

The SPEG Terminal's Environmental, Health, and & Safety Programs consist of engineering controls, administrative controls, and personal protective equipment (PPE) to effectively manage the hazardous chemicals and prevent releases.

Engineering controls include:

?! Pressure relief valves on stationary tanks to prevent over-pressurization of vessels during loading activities and fire

?! Comprehensive system of relief values, emergency and set point monitors, and alarms

?! Gas monitoring devices strategically located throughout the facility to detect leaks in piping systems, tanks, and railcars

?! Comprehensive security systems to prevent inadvertent access to the site by unwanted guests and to monitor who is requesting access to the site

?! The dike containment system for the seasonal storage tanks

?! The automatic flare system to mitigate over-pressurization of the storage system

?! Additional refrigeration system installed in 2010 upstream of, and in-line with, the existing system to mitigate and control over-pressurization of the bulk storage tanks during filling (loading) operations

?! Fire detection, suppression, and deluge systems to mitigate spread of fire in an emergency

?! Automatic and emergency shutdown systems

Administrative controls include:

?! Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for process operations to control and mitigate high-risk events below critical conditions

?! Standard procedures for maintenance of equipment and critical safety devices

?! Safe work procedures (Lockout/tagout, confined space entry, line break, hot work, etc.)

?! Contractor safety standards

?! Training, both site specific and industry general, including certifications

?! Monthly safety meetings

?! Administrative and operational procedures to ensure routine inspections of the site are completed on a regular schedule and documented consistent with the site's Injury Illness Prevention Program

PPE includes:

?! Thermal gloves to protect against cryogens

?! Fire resistant (i.e.ie, Nomex) outer garments for sampling

?! Safety glasses

Through properly designed storage and transfer systems and equipment, trained personnel, and PPE, the site has minimized the impact of an accident to its employees and to the general public.

1.2 Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled

SPEG is a bulk storage and transfer facility for liquid propane, Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) Code 5171/ North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) Code 424710: Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Bulk Stations and Terminals. Propane is the only regulated substance handled at the facility.

The SPEG is designed to receive and ship LPG by either rail or tanker. The SPEG Terminal's storage capacity consists of two refrigerated bulk storage tanks (seasonal storage tanks), each with a storage capacity of 11 million gallons, and four 60,000-gallon pressurized temporary storage tanks (blimps).

1.3 The Worst-Case Release Scenario

The Worst-Case Release Scenario (WRS) predicted for the facility would involve a release from the four interconnected 60,000-gallon pressurized temporary storage tanks (blimps). The volume released in 10 minutes would result in a vapor cloud explosion. The resulting distance to the endpoint extends offsite, and public receptors are within the distance to the end point.

1.4 Alternative Case Release Scenario

The most credible Alternative Release Scenario (ARS) predicted for the facility would involve a release from a single, refrigerated, seasonal storage tank; resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. The resulting distance to the endpoint extends offsite, and public receptors are within the distance to the endpoint.

1.5 Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

SPEG is operated and maintained in accordance with applicable federal, state, local, and industry-specific codes, regulations, and standards, including:

?! USEPA's Accidental Release Prevention requirements in accordance with Title 40, Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Part 68

?! Federal and state PSM standards, codified at 29 CFR 1910.119 and Title 8, California Code of Regulations (CCR), Section 5189

?! CalARP, in accordance with Chapter 4.5 of Title 19, CCR, Sections 2735.1-2785.1

?! The United States Department of Transportation requirements for the handling and transport of hazardous materials, in accordance with 49 CFR 126

1.6 Five-Year Accident History

Since construction and startup operations in 1971 through 1973, there has not been an accidental release of propane, the regulated chemical, at the SPEG that has resulted in or could have resulted in any serious injuries, deaths, or property or environmental damage, evacuations or shelter in place responses.

1.7 Emergency Response Program

SPEG maintains a comprehensive Emergency Action Plan, which details specific procedures to be implemented by site personnel in the event of an emergency, including:

?! Process and equipment shutdown procedures

?! Fire protection procedures

?! Evacuation procedures

?! Emergency Responder notification procedures

?! Public notification procedures

?! Post-emergency investigation and reporting requirements

?! Post-emergency process systems inspection and startup procedures

SPEG maintains onsite firefighting and emergency response systems and equipment to support and augment offsite emergency response resources as well. The site's emergency response systems and equipment are maintained by qualified Fire System maintenance contractors in accordance with National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) standards.

SPEG's Emergency Action Plan has been coordinated with local offsite responders, including:

?! Sacramento Metropolitan Fire District, Consumes River Division

?! Elk Grove Fire Department

?! Elk Grove Police Department

?! Sacramento County Sheriff's Department

As noted above, effective 2010, SPEG Terminal is subject to the CFATS regulations of DHS in accordance with Title 6, CFR, Domestic Security. Personnel access to information subject to CFATS regulations is restricted to a 'need to know' basis and requires personnel to obtain DHS Chemical-Terrorism Vulnerability Information (CVI) in accordance with 6 CCR 27.

Disclosure of any information contain

ed in and/or covered by the 2010 CVI submittal to DHS; and used in and/or generated during the 2014 Security Vulnerability Assessment (SVA), including site security information referenced in either past RMP updates and/or this 2019 RMP update, is restricted in accordance with 6 CFR 27.400. The information must be treated as federally classified information in accordance with 6 CFR 27.400 (h) and (i) and may only be released to persons with a 'need to know' in accordance with 6 CFR 27.400 (e).

1.8 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The 2014 RMP update (submitted in 2016) included a revalidation of the 2009 Process Hazard Assessment (PHA) (submitted in 2010). As a result of that most-recent PHA revalidation, and the 3-Year Certified Unified Program Agency (CUPA) Audits conducted in 2016 and 2019, SPEG Terminal has completed implementation of the following process safety improvements:

?! Formalized Site Safety Inspection Procedure and developed/implemented PM Procedure for inspection and maintenance of process and equipment integrity

?! Effective 2012, updated PPE Program to require Fire Protective Clothing use by site personnel; and updated operating and PM procedures incorporating the requirement into the critical SOPs and continue to add to SOPs as deemed appropriate

?! Effective 2019, incorporated a statement of safe operating parameters and Consequences of Deviation statement in operating, PM, and safe work practice (SWP) procedures; this is continuing

?! Implemented formal written quarterly safety inspections of the facility per the Injury and Illness Prevention Program (IIPP) to include observations for equipment repairs and safety concerns

?! Drafted new job function/description for Assistant Plant Manager - Maintenance Supervisor to ensure adequate management support levels during hours of operations
